Hi...,

I'm in the process of converting (or trying to) a module to BD... It's my first attempt.

In the docs @ https://api.backdropcms.org/converting-modules-from-drupal the paragraph "Let Backdrop know about your module's config"

It doesn't explicitly say where to put the function "Implements hook_config_info()." I've spent 30 minutes searching but can't find it :frown:

Then I had an epiphany, look at another module :smile: ok, more of a DOH! moment :smile:

So, would it be worth putting the file it needs to be saved in, in the help text?

Regards

Steve
I think the general idea is that all functions go in a module's .module file, unless otherwise specified...

How does this look:

Let Backdrop know about your module's config
Modules need to declare config files in hook_config_info() in the .module file. This is how Backdrop knows that you have a config file that needs to copied when the module is enabled. It's also how Backdrop compares changes in config during deployment, and how it knows which config files need to be automatically removed when uninstalling a module.
Yeah, I 'm beginning to realise, but I did waste a bit of time trying to figure it out... and for noobs general ideas aren't always obvious :smile: lol
@Steve Moorhouse - I added "in the .module" file to the first line. Would that have helped and is that accurate?
Please, keep giving suggestions on how to improve this documentation. It's great to have fresh eyes.
FYI, nitpicking, it doesnt have to be in the module file, if there is an include_once() or such which includes whatever file where it is.
(that was an uncomfortable sentence, hope its not too cryptic)
:smile:
@docwilmot - No, thanks. How can I phrase this better for a future @Steve Moorhouse?
TBH I think its fine as it is. If youre using includes, you probably arent a noob, and you'd know this.
OK, good.
Yeah, was nitpicking as noted.
Well, sometimes nitpicking is good. I don't want to confuse folks.
Agreed... I'm not a noob at programming and design, but I've a lot to learn about PHP and how Drupal and BD work :smile:
But, I also want to take advantage of the fresh eyes of @Steve Moorhouse and help future newcomers avoid the same frustrations.
While @docwilmot is correct I can't imagine why someone would not want to put it in .module

@StPaulTim

Please, keep giving suggestions on how to improve this documentation. It's great to have fresh eyes.
